content.description: Carol, a reporter in a large city, took a random sample of <math alttext="300" overflow="scroll"><mn>300</mn></math> households and found that the <math alttext="90" overflow="scroll"><mn>90</mn></math> percent confidence interval for the proportion of households that own a pet is <math alttext="open parenthesis, 0.63 comma 0.71, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mn>0.63</mn></mpadded><mo>,</mo><mpadded><mn>0.71</mn></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>. Jason, the director of a local animal shelter, wants to verify this result for the proportion of households that own a pet and takes a different random sample of <math alttext="200" overflow="scroll"><mn>200</mn></math> households and finds that <math alttext="67" overflow="scroll"><mn>67</mn></math> percent own a pet.
content.question: Assume the conditions for inference have been met. Jason will calculate a <math alttext="90" overflow="scroll"><mn>90</mn></math> percent confidence interval for the proportion of households that own a pet using his sample data. How would the margin of error from Jason's confidence interval compare to the margin of error from Carol's confidence interval?

choices.label: Jason’s margin of error would be the same as Carol’s margin of error because the confidence level did not change.
Jason’s margin of error would be the same as Carol’s margin of error because the point estimate did not change.
Jason’s margin of error would be less than Carol’s margin of error because Jason used a smaller sample size.
Jason’s margin of error would be greater than Carol’s margin of error because Jason used a smaller sample size.
Jason’s margin of error would be greater than Carol’s margin of error because Jason’s point estimate is greater.

content.answer: Jason’s margin of error would be greater than Carol’s margin of error because Jason used a smaller sample size.
